metadata.title: Experimental investigation for entropy generation and exergy loss of nano-refrigerant condensation process

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate / i jhmt
Experimental investigation for entropy generation and exergy loss of nano-refrigerant condensation process
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijheatmasstransfer.2018.04.155 0017-9310/ 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: mohsen.sheikholeslami@nit.ac.ir, mohsen.sheikholeslami@
yahoo.com (M. Sheikholeslami), zhixiong.li@knights.ucf.edu (Z. Li).
M. Sheikholeslami a,⇑, Milad Darzi b, Zhixiong Li c,d,⇑ aDepartment of Mechanical Engineering, Babol Noshirvani University of Technology, Babol, Iran bDepartment of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65211, USA c School of Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao 266110, China d School of Mechanical, Materials, Mechatronic and Biomedical Engineering, University of Wollongong, Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia
a r t i c l e i n f o a b s t r a c t
Article history: Received 15 March 2018 Received in revised form 29 April 2018 Accepted 30 April 2018
Keywords: Entropy generation Heat transfer Nano-refrigerant Exergy loss Condensation Experimental approach
In this research, entropy generation and exergy loss of nano-refrigerant condensation process inside a horizontal tube is investigated experimentally. Mixture of oil and CuO nanoparticles is added to R600a and nano-refrigerant is produced. Influences of vapor quality, mass flux, concentration of nanoparticles on entropy generation and exergy loss are investigated. Results indicate that increasing concentration of nanoparticles leads to increase the frictional entropy generation. Bejan number and exergy loss decreases with increase of vapor quality and mass flux of nanofluid.
2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Heat transfer capacity is required to rise to meet the increasing demand of energy density and this can be achieved by using fluid with higher thermophysical characteristics. Recently, dispersing nanoparticles of solid materials in traditional fluids, nanofluids, has become a popular way to increase the thermal characteristics of working fluids in heat exchangers [1]. The heat transfer enhancement employing nanofluids possibly affected by different mechanisms such as Brownian motion, sedimentation, dispersion of the suspended particles, thermophoresis, and ballistic phonon transport. Some well-known examples of nanoparticles are metal oxides, metals, or carbon based particles with the diameter of less than 100 nm. Several researchers have investigated the performance of heat exchangers using nanofluids [2–6].
Ding et al. [7] have claimed that 1% volume fraction CNT-R-113 nanorefrigerants can increase the thermal conductivity up to 82% compared with the pure refrigerant. Adding nanoparticles augments the solubility between the refrigerant and the lubricant.
Based on an experimental research carried out by Wang et al. [8], TiO2 nanoparticles can be used as nanoparticles to increase the solubility between the oil and pure refrigerant. Recent studies on nanorefrigerants have proven that mixing specific mass fraction of nanoparticles and refrigerant caused a significant enhancement in the condensing heat transfer (CHT) coefficient. Park and Jung [9] have reported the maximum heat transfer enhancement of 36.6% in pool boiling of CNT nanorefrigerant with the pure refrigerants of R22, R123 and R134. Sheikholeslami et al. [10] investigated the effect of adding nanoparticles on pure refrigerant and then they examined the roles of mass flux, vapor quality, concentration of nanoparticles on heat transfer coefficient. Their results suggested that the presence of nanoparticles generally increase the frictional pressure drop. They concluded that the Brownian motion as well as the deposition of a molecular layer of nanoparticles on the inner tube surface intensifies the conduction and micro-convection in the fluid. Another recent experimental study has been carried out by Yang et al. [11] to investigate the flow boiling heat transfer and pressure drop characteristics of R600a in a smooth horizontal tube with an inner diameter of 6 mm. After comparing the experimental data with the calculated data of seven well-known correlations, they indicated that, the correlation of Liu and Winterton [12] showed the best agreement with a mean absolute relative deviation of 11.5%. However, for two-phase frictional pressure
Nomenclature
Cp specific heat [J kg 1 K 1] D inner diameter of the tube [m] d diameter of nanoparticle [m] G mass flux [kg m 2 s 1] h enthalpy [kJ kg 1] m mass flow rate [kg s 1] Q heat transfer rate [W] Dp pressure drop [pa] T temperature [ C] x vapor quality [–] w mass fraction of nanoparticles [–] Qheat evaporator heat transfer rate, [W] h heat transfer coefficient, [W/m2 K] Qtest condenser heat transfer rate, [W]
Greek symbols e void fraction [–] q density [kg m 3] r surface tension [N m 1] u volume fraction of nanoparticles [–]
Subscripts v vapor cw cooling water e evaporator f frictional h homogenous in inlet of the test section mom momentum s static tot total l liquid n nanoparticle no nominal o oil out outlet of the test section r refrigerant ra Rouhani-Axelsson test test section
drop, they have not observed a positive effect from mass flux on frictional pressure drop, while negative effect was found for saturation pressure. For the feasibility of nanoparticle dispersion into the refrigerant, Darzi et al. [13], utilized Polyester oil (POE) as lubricant oil and added to the pure refrigerant by 1% mass fraction and have investigated various values of mass flux, vapor quality, concentration of nanoparticle. They claimed that adding nanoparticles leads to enhance frictional pressure drop. Nanoparticles caused larger pressure drop penalty at relatively lower vapor qualities which may be attributed to the existing condensation flow pattern such that annular flow is less influenced by nanoparticles compared to intermittent flow regime
On the basis of the comprehensive literature review, it is revealed that the effect of using nanofluids on the exergy loss in a heat exchanger had rarely been reported and not so clear. Wu et al. [14] have defined exergy transfer effectiveness to evaluate the efficiency of heat exchangers operating above/below the surrounding temperature with/without finite pressure drop. They also compared the exergy transfer effectiveness with heat transfer effectiveness for the parallel flow, counter flow and cross flow heat exchangers. Khairul et al. [15] has been investigated the heat transfer performance and exergy analyses of a corrugated plate heat exchanger using metal oxide nanofluids. Exergy loss was reduced by 24% employing nanofluids as a heat transfer medium with comparing to conventional fluid. Besides, 34% higher exegetic heat transfer effectiveness was found for 1.5 vol% of nanoparticles. However this study has been mainly focused on only single phase heat transfer and the effect of phase change heat transfer has not been studies. Recently various publications were presented application of nanofluid for heat transfer [16–28].
To the authors’ best knowledge, no research has been performed on second law analysis of heat exchangers in multiphase flows. In this study, the main reason for choosing CuO/water as the nanofluids is its excellent thermophysical properties at an affordable cost. Moreover, the majority of the researches were carried out by using conventional fluids rather than nanofluids in the heat exchanger. The scope of the present study is to investigate the heat transfer coefficient, the heat transfer rate, the friction factor, pressure drop, and the exergy loss characteristics of nanofluid based refrigerant in a heat exchanger.

sections.heading: 2.1. Experimental apparatus
sections.text:
Fig. 1 represents the overall schematic of the experimental setup. The main components are flow meter, gear pump, evaporator, test condenser, post condenser, receiver and bypass path line. A gear pump circulates the liquid phase of refrigerant in the loop while the mass flow rate of refrigerant was adjusted by connecting an inventor to the gear pump. In order to measure the flow rate, a rotameter with the accuracy of ± 1% of full scale was used. To ensure the working fluid at the inlet of test section (test condenser) is in a saturated condition with predefined vapor quality, an evaporator was installed before the test condenser. The working fluid, however, was heated up beforehand by using a heater before goes to the evaporator. Then, the working fluid enters the test condenser which is a counter flow heat exchanger with the inner tube of 8.7 mm internal diameter. The cooling water also flowed in the annulus. Two pressure gauges (EN 837–1 Wika model) with the accuracy of 10 kPa were installed to measure the inlet and outlet
Table 1 CuO-nanoparticle characteristics.
Isobaric specific heat [j/kg/K] Purity (%) Density [g/cm3] Diameter [nm] Thermal conductivity [W/m/K]
550.5 99.8 6.32 40 32.9
pressures of the test condenser. Also, a differential pressure transducer (PDM-75 model) was utilized to measure the pressure drop along the test condenser. In order to ensure that the working fluid is in liquid phase before entering the gear pump, a shell-and-tube heat exchanger as a post-condenser was used after the test section and also a cylindrical shell was placed as a receiver after the postcondenser.
In this study, Isobutene (R600a, 99.5% purity) was selected as a pure refrigerant and Polyolester oil (POE) was used as a lubricant. In order to create baseline mixture (refrigerant/oil) or nanorefrigerant (refrigerant/oil/nanoparticle) flows, a by-pass was used to inject the oil or oil/nanoparticles in the system.

sections.heading: 2.2. Working fluids
sections.text:
The refrigerant used in the present experiment was Isobutene (R600a) which is an environmental-friendly refrigerant with low Global Warming Potential (GWP) and zero Ozone Depletion Potential (ODP). Polyolester oil (POE) which is soluble in Isobutene was utilized as a lubricant and added to the pure refrigerant by 1% mass fraction aiming to create a baseline refrigerant/oil mixture. POE has the nominal kinematic viscosity of72.3 mm2/s at 40 C. Nanoparticle used in this study was Copper oxide (CuO) with 40 nm in diameter. Table 1 lists the main features of the nanoparticles used in the present study.
A digital electronic balance was used to disperse nanoparticles with various mass fractions in POE and an ultrasonic device (UP400S, Hielscher GmbH) was utilized to vibrate the mixture of oil and nanoparticles for an hour, at 400 W and 20 kHz to create a uniform mixture. The homogenized mixture of oil/nanoparticles was then injected to the pure refrigerant.
The dispersion of the nanofluid was monitored for 12 h which no substantial sedimentation was observed. A sight glass was installed in the system to monitor the deposition of the nanofluid during the operation process in which the amount of observed deposition was trivial. Each case for experiment was carried out for less than 8 h. However, the nano-refrigerants were detected to be stable for more than 12 h. The uncertainties of the instruments and calculated parameters are provided in Table 2. The method presented by Schultz et al. [29] has been utilized.

sections.heading: 3. Data reduction
sections.text:
Nominal oil concentration in mixture is calculated by:
xno ¼ momo þmR ð1Þ
where mo is the oil’s mass flow rate and mR is the refrigerant’s mass flow rate. Local oil concentration is calculated from the percentage of oil in liquid phase:
xloc ¼ momo þmR;L ¼ xno 1 xR;o ð2Þ
where mR;L, xR;o and xloc are the mass flow rate of refrigerant liquid, vapor quality of oil/refrigerant mixture and local oil concentration, respectively.
where xR;0, hR;o,ho, hR;l and hR;V are the mixture’s quality, the mixture’s, lubricant’s and refrigerant in the liquid phase’s and vapor phase’s enthalpy respectively.
The enthalpy at the inlet and outlet of the test section is calculated as:
hR;o;in ¼ hR;o;1 þ Qheatmo þmR ð4Þ
hR;o;out ¼ hR;o;in Q testmo þmR ð5Þ
where hR;o;1 is obtained by knowing the pressure and temperature of the enthalpy of the single phase mixture at the inlet of the heater. Qheat is the required heat to vaporize the working fluid in the heater and creates the saturated condition at the inlet of the test section. Q test is the condensation heat transfer rate at the test condenser
and is calculated from the mass flow rate and temperature difference of cooling water:
Q test ¼ mwCp;wðT in ToutÞ ð6Þ
where mw, Cp;w, T in and Tout are respectively the cooling water’s mass flow rate, specific heat ratio and temperatures at the inlet and outlet of the heat exchanger.
The average quality of the working fluid along the test section is readily given by:
ðxR;oÞave ¼ ðxR;oÞin þ ðxR;oÞout

where Ai is the area for heat transfer, Ts is the refrigerant’s saturated temperature and Twall is the inner wall temperature of the test condenser. During the experiment, the outer wall temperatures were measured. Therefore, to find the inner wall temperature, the conduction through the tube wall thickness was taken into account using the conduction calculation in cylindrical coordinate system:
Twall ¼ Tth þ Qr2pLKCu ln Do Di

where Tth;Di;Do; L; and KCu are the average temperature at a cross section along the test condenser, inner and outer tube diameters, length of the test condenser, and thermal conductivity of tube wall, respectively. However, the difference between Tth and Twall was insignificant owing to the high conductivity of copper.
The two-phase frictional pressure drop DPf is calculated from the measured total pressure drop along the rest condenser as:
Dpf ¼ Dptot Dpstatic Dpmom ð10Þ where DPtot is the total pressure drop and was directly measured by the differential pressure transducer installed in the test section. sections.heading: 4. Results and discussion
sections.text:
In this paper, second law analysis of nanofluid condensation process is investigated. CuO is selected as nanoparticles which are added into oil and dispersed to R600a. The CHT coefficients of pure refrigerant in the tube test section are measured and compared with previous work [35] (see Fig. 2(a)). Second verification is demonstrated in Fig. 2(b) to prove the accuracy of the experimental systems was assessed by measuring the frictional pressure drop of pure R600a [36].
There comparisons demonstrate a good agreement. Influences of mass fraction of nanofluid (0–1%), mass fluxes from (154.6 to 265.4 kg m 2s 1) and vapor qualities (0.11–0.78) on entropy generation and exergy loss are investigated. The following formulas for Sgen;f ; Sgen;th;Be and Xd can be presented according to experimental data
S gen;f ¼ 105Sgen;f ¼ 0:7þ 0:83xþ 0:023wþ 0:49Gþ 0:014xwþ 0:42xG
þ 0:56x2 ð19Þ
Sgen;th ¼ 0:031 0:014x 2:8 10 3w 8:5 10 3Gþ 2:23 10 3xwþ 6:34 10 3xGþ 7:8 10 3x2 ð20Þ
G; x;w on Xd .
Be ¼ 1 4:2 10 4x 2:5 10 4w 2:4 10 5G 2:39 10 5xw 2:55 10 4xG 1:15 10 5wG 2:6 10 4x2 ð21Þ
Xd ¼ 9:06 4:08x 0:85w 2:52Gþ 0:66xwþ 1:87xG þ 0:43wGþ 2:31x2 ð22Þ
Fig. 3 shows the influences of mass flux (G), vapor quality (x), and nanoparticle concentration (w) on entropy generation caused by friction (Sgen,f). It is seen that higher amount of entropy is generated at higher vapor quality or mass flux due to the significant increase in condensation frictional pressure drop with vapor quality (x) and mass flux (G). On the other hand, nanoparticles have a small impact on condensing frictional pressure drop penalty and therefore caused insignificant influence on entropy generation caused by friction (Sgen,f).
The effects of G, x and w on the generated entropy caused by heat transfer (Sgen,th) is shown in Fig. 4. It is apparent from the result that increasing either the mass flux, vapor quality or nanoparticle concentration led to a smaller entropy generation caused by heat transfer (Sgen,th). This is due to the enhancement of condensation heat transfer coefficient (and Nusselt number) under almost same heat flux. It is widely known that two-phase heat transfer coefficient is dramatically increased by mass flux and vapor quality. Nanoparticles also play a remarkable role on condensing heat transfer in such a way that even a small fraction of nanoparticles cause a substantial enhance in condensing heat transfer coefficient (and accordingly Nusselt number). This effect results in a lesser entropy generation caused by heat transfer (Sgen,th).
Fig. 5 indicates the variation of Bejan number affected by G, x and w. Bejan number represents the ratio of entropy generated by heat transfer to total of heat transfer and friction. As illustrated in Figs. 3 and 4, by increasing G or x, entropy generated by friction Sgen,f is increased whereas the generated entropy by heat transfer Sgen,th is reduced. The balance between those two will determine the Bejan number caused by G or x. It is illustrated that Bejan number is slightly increased when G or x are decreased. However, the variations of Be are still very small (less than 0.08%) which means the order of magnitude of Sgen,th is greater than Sgen,f.
For the nanoparticle concentration (w), the scenario is a bit different. Nanoparticles’ effect is only observed on Sgen,th (Fig. 4) and it has almost nothing to do with Sgen,f (Fig. 3). Therefore, the variation of Bejan number is only the function of Sgen,th in both numerator and denominator in the definition (Eq. (18)) and therefore will be canceled out. This means nanoparticles do not influence on Bejan number or at least the effect is trivial. This is clearly manifested in the results presented in Fig. 5. Fig. 6 shows the amount of destroyed exergy (Xd) with respect to G, x and w. It is seen that destroyed exergy is smaller at higher mass flux or vapor quality. This is attributed to the larger order of magnitude of the reduced Sgen,th compared to the augmented Sgen,f at higher G or x. Additionally, it is shown that Xd is higher at the lower nanoparticle concentrations due to the reduced Sgen,th at higher w as discussed earlier.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
Entropy generation and exergy loss of nano-refrigerant is studied during condensation process. R600a/oil/CuO nano-refrigerants are considered as working fluid. Results demonstrate that Sgen;f increase with rise of x;w;G and it can be found that effect of vapor quality is not sensible in comparison of two other parameters. Augmenting x;w;G reduces the thermal entropy generation. Bejan number decreases with increase of vapor quality. Also, exergy loss
is a decreasing function of mass fraction of nanofluid, mass flux and vapor quality.
